title: Value curve
description: The line on a strategy canvas showing the emphasis a company places on each factor of competition in its industry.
html:
A value curve is the result of plotting a company on a Strategy canvas.

Red ocean value curves

When a company and its competitors have similarly shaped or converging value curves, they are likely to be in a Red ocean.

Blue ocean value curves

Two of the three common traits of successful blue ocean strategies appear on a value curve. These make value curves an excellent way to identify Blue ocean strategies. These traits are focus and divergence. Focus appears as a small number of Factors of competition with very high emphasis. Divergence appears as a value curve with a shape that diverges from the rest of the industry.

When looking at a companyâ€™s value curve on a Strategy canvas, their focus (or lack thereof) is identified by a small number of Factors of competition which are heavily emphasized. Typically some other factors are eliminated or reduced compared to the rest of the industry. These attributes highlight the companyâ€™s value innovation

Analyzing a companyâ€™s value curve on a Strategy canvas, itâ€™s possible to identify divergence by looking for a value curve with a unique shape that differs from others in the industry.

Other insights from value curves

When a value curve shows high emphasis across a many Factors of competition, evaluate whether the company is over-delivering without benefit. Such expensive investments need to be justified, such as by greater profits, substantial market share, or establishing a moat to isolate against competition.

Over-delivering is when a company is investing in features or Factors of competition that provide limited incremental value for customers.

When a companyâ€™s value curve zig-zags across the Strategy canvas, it may be a sign of an incoherent strategy. While each decision may be reasonable in isolation, itâ€™s unlikely that there is a unifying strategy behind them.
